item.title: Coffee and Open Source Conversation - Dennis Doomen
item.description:
Dennis is a Microsoft MVP and Principal Consultant at Dutch Microsoft consultancy firm Aviva Solutions. With 27 years of experience under his belt as a software architect and/or lead developer, he specializes in designing full-stack enterprise solutions based on .NET as well as providing coaching on all aspects of designing, building, documenting, deploying and maintaining software systems in an agile world. He is the author of Fluent Assertions, an assertion library to make your unit tests look great, Liquid Projections, a set of libraries for building Event Sourcing projections and he has been maintaining coding guidelines for C# since 2001. You can find him on Twitter, Mastodon and BlueSky.
You can follow Dennis on Social Media https://bsky.app/profile/dennisdoomen.com https://x.com/ddoomen https://www.linkedin.com/in/dennisdoomen https://github.com/dennisdoomen https://www.dennisdoomen.com/
PLEASE SUBSCRIBE TO THE PODCAST
- Spotify: http://isaacl.dev/podcast-spotify - Apple Podcasts: http://isaacl.dev/podcast-apple - Google Podcasts: http://isaacl.dev/podcast-google - RSS: http://isaacl.dev/podcast-rss
You can check out more episodes of Coffee and Open Source on https://www.coffeeandopensource.com
Coffee and Open Source is hosted by Isaac Levin (https://twitter.com/isaacrlevin)
item.author: (Isaac Levin)

item.title: The demoscene as a UNESCO heritage in Sweden
item.description: The demoscene has become a national UNESCO-heritage in Sweden, thanks to an application that Ziphoid and me did last year. item.title: Why I'm Breaking Up With Vibe Coding
item.description: We‚Äôve all been there: headphones on, music pumping, fingers flying across the keyboard, lost in the ‚Äúflow‚Äù with your favorite AI agent. This, my friends, is vibe coding. It‚Äôs when you‚Äôre in the zone, seemingly effortlessly producing code. It‚Äôs the idea that you can create great software simply by immersing yourself in the feeling of coding, trusting your intuition and riding the wave of inspiration. But lately, I‚Äôve realized that for me, at least, the vibe is‚Ä¶off.

item.title: I Got an M, Not an F
item.description: In my elementary school, we weren‚Äôt given grades of A B C D F as was the standard before and since. Instead, New Haven R-II school employed a different set of letters that meant the same thing. They were E S M I F. I have no idea how this came to pass, but I hope it was because some person seeking a doctorate in education realized that his dissertation was due tomorrow and he had nothing. Frankly, I could get behind that kind of education theory. Beats modern pedagogy, anyway.

item.title: Cautions on being 'experiment driven'
item.description:
I hear a lot of people say they want their startup to be more ‚Äòexperiment driven‚Äô. I‚Äôve encouraged that behaviour a lot myself. Take bets, see how they progress, gather data and use the result to validate, or invalidate some sort of hypothesis.
